body:
Comment 3 by **Kalthorn**: 
It does have the Equifax certificate.  That was true even before I manually added the
Google one.

In order to try with IE, I had to re-enable IE9 in "Turn Windows Features on or off"
dialog.  I received no warning from your link which is expected since I had added the
certificate manually.  I then deleted the certificate I added (via Microsoft Management
Console) and IE still accepted the HTTPS connection to Google Code.  Using "go get" also
worked and continues to work even though I have again turned IE off.  Reboots throughout
of course.  In short, I can't reproduce the problem.

I never tried Alex's initial suggestion through the mailing list, which is what you just
suggested: try through IE and see what it says (and then try to 'go get' right after if
successful).  I didn't try because I had IE disabled and didn't want to go through a
reboot right then.  Is it possible that IE needs to vet the certificate through the
chain?  I tried clearing IE's certificate cache (it had google listed as verified
through Equifax) but that also had no effect.

The final bit of info I can add is that this is a fresh install of Windows 7, although I
had already updated to SP1 and almost every security update.
